citeinfo.origin: Federal Institute for Fisheries and Oceanography
citeinfo.title: Climate-linked Changes in Main Commercial Stock Fluctuations in the Atlantic and Pacific.

descript.abstract: Global impacts of fishing on marine ecosystems can be reliably evaluated against the background of natural longterm changes, observed in these ecosystems. Main commercial species (Peruvian, Japanese and Californian sardine, anchovy, pacific, salmon, walleye Pollock, Chilean jack mackerel, Pacific and Atlantic herring, cod, and some others) producing about 50 percent of world marine fish harvest undergo long-term simultaneous oscillations.
descript.purpose: To show the climate-linked Changes in main commercial stock fluctuations in the Atlantic and Pacific.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system.
